subject: Re: Classic example
author: Loretta
full_text:
Ann and all, 

About the Luminator....I have seen Luminator pictures where the 
ceiling light was displaced and somewhat distorted. If whatever the 
Luminator does can displace a ceiling light, surely it can also 
displace a human face. 

Loretta

--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, Lisby <lisby@...> wrote:
>
> 
> On Dec 29, 2007, at 6:15 PM, Ursula Bielski wrote:
> 
> >
> > I don't know as there are "hundreds" of examples available to 
the  
> > public in the way of Luminator photographs,
> 
> I didn't say that. I said there are hundreds of examples on line 
of  
> known long exposures. When even a few of these are compared with  
> Luminator examples, I see a tremendous similarity. Do you?
> 
> 
> > but there are a couple of dozen in Macy's book, "Spirit Faces," 
and  
> > yes, many many of them are open to wide interpretation,
> 
> Does that mean that you agree with my point? Because, as I reason  
> it,  they are either spirit extras or they aren't. They can't sort-
of  
> be spirit extras. I'm not sure what other interpretations there 
might  
> be in this instance.
> 
> 
> > just as our humble recordings are.
> 
> >   In addition to that majority that make us say, "Come on!{" 
there  
> > are a handful that make you say "Hmmmmmmm. . . ." Just like we  
> > offer a handful of results from our endless recording efforts to  
> > try to convince the hard-nosed.
> 
> I'd agree with you wholeheartedly, if I had ever seen one that 
did,  
> in fact, make me go, "Hmmmm." As I said, I have never seen one 
where  
> the sitter and the extra did not share a consistent set of 
features  
> and coloring. If you have any examples that do, and you can share  
> them, I'd be delighted to see them. I'd like my opinion to be 
swayed.  
> Really, I would.
> 
> > I would think that many would see the Luminator efforts as a 
modern  
> > effort at scrying.
> 
> Do you mean scrying as in the psychomanteum method developed by  
> Raymond Moody? My understanding, from attending a presentation by 
Dr.  
> Moody, was that the psychomanteum produced full-blown apparitions  
> that could converse with the bereaved. Not sure these two types of  
> events are comparable.
> 
> > Everything we do crosses boundaries, and my point is that it's  
> > really hard to walk the line between trying to be scientific and  
> > trying to be open.  It's really, really hard! But if we give in 
one  
> > area, we have to be willing to give in another.
> 
> I don't think that is arguably true, Ursula. If the evidence 
appears  
> good, I acknowledge it; if the evidence appears weak, I 
acknowledge  
> it. It is simply not true to say that a person cannot be both open- 
> minded and scientific. I really do want to believe, but I won't  
> believe just because I want to. And because you, me, or anyone  
> "gives" in one area, does not make a phenomenon any more or less 
real.
> 
> Your fellow traveler on this journey,
> 
> Ann
> 
> 
> 
> > Ursula
> >
> >
> > Lisby <lisby@...> wrote:
> > This is a classic example of the kind of photo that Mark thinks 
shows
> > a spirit extra. To me, clearly, this is the same woman--same hair,
> > same eyes, same mouth, same nose. Again, to me, it looks like a
> > classic long exposure when compared with other known long 
exposures--
> > I've included just of hundreds of examples.
> >
> > Ann
> >
> >
> >
>
